comments.text:
Wow.... Thanks for the information, although I was somewhat confused, is 
what you're saying that ingested drugs would be in effective because the 
durg would not get far enough in the body to be effective? And that pills 
would basically breakdown Necessary and unnecessarily proteins in cells, 
Now that I think about it, a non specialized pill could break down the 
protein hemoglobin in blood cells, such as red and white, where HIV wreaks 
havoc.  And like you said, "shape fits function" and hemoglibins are what 
make red blood cells that almost doughnut- like squishy shape that allows 
them to fit through veins and capillaries.
comments.author: Dorian D.

comments.text:
+prei tek [Not trying to make a fool out you, just giving the technical 
facts to an otherwise inquisitive person] Ingestion is far less effective 
than vaccination due to the fact that, during digestion, your body is 
trying to break down whatever is put into it (especially things like 
proteins {the likely drug in question} ab intra the stomach). This is 
doubly so in the case of HIV (a virus, or complex protein, not a bacterium) 
as it affects the immune system; the drug would have to get to the small 
intestine (again, it still has to get through the destructive stomach 
first) before it's even close the lymphatic system, let alone the 
circulatory system. If you're instead referring to a pill, you'd have to be 
using a relatively simple (relative to a protein, that is) chemical to keep 
from losing effectiveness in a solid, pill form. This works when we're 
dealing with combating microorganisms (like bacteria) because said chemical 
would only have to affect one of many necessary functions (such as the 
breakdown of nutrients, the separation of the cell, etc.) wherein a virus, 
being nothing but a complex chemical, requires none of that for its one 
action: "reproduction" (it's in this way that our complexity becomes our 
downfall). Proteins can really only be taken down in one way: denaturation, 
or the alteration of one (or more) of their structure levels (how the 
protein is shaped and ultimately, how it acts {remember the mantra, "form 
fits function"}). There are, however, chemicals capable of carrying out 
denaturation, though these chemicals (examples of which include sulfuric 
acid) have a way of denaturing any protein they come in contact with 
(including the one that you need to survive). This is than amplified by the 
fact that pills are "dumb"; there is not way of effectively controlling 
what they interact with. The solution comes back to proteins which can be 
designed to attack certain chemical bonds (such as those in a virus). These 
proteins are, of course, called antibodies and produced by the immune 
system. With HIV (along with any virus that leads to immunodeficiency), 
however, your immune system becomes too damaged before you're able to 
develop an antibody to fit HIV's ever-changing form. This, of course, is 
what makes HIV so complicating and hard to fight and why the cure will 
likely have to be man made. My  point in all of this is: the cure for HIV 
would have to be in the form of a protein-based injection (hopefully, you 
gleamed some other facts from this as well). Cheers!

comments.text:
Ok, you all are correct in that a risk, such as that to prevent small pox, 
can be justified if it yields a benefit to the many. However, a decision 
which involves riskiness is only glorified after the good outcome is 
achieved. Due to a principle of uncertainty regarding this matter (not to 
be confused with that of quantum mechanics), risky decisions may actually 
result in undesired consequences. People evoke sympathy for the suffering 
of others, so when a decision which leads to the debilitation or mortality 
of others, people may commonly reject all of what that decision maker 
stands for. A good example of this would be president Carter's decision in 
1980 to attempt to rescue hostages during the Iran Hostage Crisis. As many 
people know, the mission was a complete failure because not only were any 
hostages rescued, but also eight American service men were killed. Carter 
later lost the reelection. In the event of small pox, not only might Jenner 
have killed a young boy but also may have spread the disease even more than 
it already has, potentially causing a chain reaction of human deaths. Even 
though the disease has been almost been completely thrust out of existence 
because of his efforts, his risking of human lives must not be glorified 
but rather we should simply be relieved that he had not killed anyone 
indirectly. I am also not just attacking Edward Jenner. I want all of you 
who read this comment to consider the value of every person's life when you 
hear about an option with results as insecure as such. Yes, there exist 
some circumstances where the rejection of this kind of sacrifice may lead 
to more overall suffering than in the event of utilized sacrifice. However, 
I want to point out that it can often be unnecessary and utterly useless 
among the grand scheme of things.
comments.author: Andrew Stonnington

top_comment.text:
I love this TEDEd series of animated videos. The series pairs professional 
educators with top-notch animators to create short video lessons on a huge 
variety of topics in science, medicine and history. This episode features 
several of the early attempts to fight smallpox, a disease caused by a 
highly infectious, often fatal virus that plagued humanity for at least 
10,000 years and wasn’t fully eradicated until 1979. Physician Edward 
Jenner (1749–1823) is credited with developing the first vaccine against 
smallpox, but as the video points out, he probably wouldn’t have gotten far 
without a young boy named James Phipps, a cow and milkmaid Sarah Nelmes.

But more importantly, viewing a bigger picture, I post this as a reminder 
that we are all connected. That the deceases that arise from lack of 
resources to meet basic human needs affect everyone at the end. A little 
food for thought on our insurance/health care system and on distribution of 
resources.

Now, beware of all the toxic preservatives and other additions the new 
biotechs/pharmaceutical companies add to vaccines so they last longer, 
therefore, they can make more money. Ask your doctor for the purest 
alternatives with less or without preservatives (and read the articles I'm 
posting in the comments)... ﻿
top_comment.author: Inda Liza Luciano
